text: When was the last time Mitch McConnell just sat and listened in Kentucky? We can do better, and I will do better for Kentucky. Join our grassroots team: http://bit.ly/KYCanDoBetter
Mitch McConnell has ignored Kentuckians for too long. Here's just a glimpse into their stories.

You have a say in the future of this commonwealth and this country. Thank you to the engaged community of Pulaski County for making their voices heard today at the Mole Hole and our meet & greet at the Pulaski County Democratic HQ.  Together, we'll write a new future.

Congratulations to all the awardees honored at the 41st Annual YMCA Black Achievers Awards Celebration at the Galt House last night. They received hundreds of thousands of dollars in college scholarships. An honor to spend time with the next generation of leaders.‚Ä¨

We all just want a government that works for us‚Ä¶not one that makes us fight for what we are owed time after time.  Thank you to the Kentucky Chapter of the National Association of Letter Carriers for having me this morning. I‚Äôll fight FOR you in Washington.

Honored to attend the 26th Annual African American Heritage Breakfast & hear inspiring words from Hon. Clayton. She reminded me of what Rep. Cummings said, ‚ÄúWhen we are dancing with the angels, the question will be asked ... what did we do to make sure we kept democracy intact?‚Äù‚Ä¨

This year I‚Äôm running 5ks all across the state. Today, I‚Äôm running a race in Covington for Be Concerned, one of the largest free food pantries in Northern Kentucky. Follow along with me! #RunningForKentucky

My statement on impeachment vote: For 20 years, I served as a commissioned military officer, fighting to keep our nation safe and protect our democracy. Many of my friends died in combat to preserve the founding principles of our country. What happened in the Senate this week pushed aside fairness and the rule of law in favor of raw partisan politics. The long-term interests of our country took a backseat, yet again. It was clear from the overwhelming evidence provided by the House, and the refusal of the White House to provide the witnesses and documents requested, that the president withheld vital national security assistance to Ukraine in order to pressure them to investigate a political opponent. Our national security is not a bargaining chip. For this reason alone, I would have voted to impeach and convict on both counts. Republican senators could have forced the president to tell the American people the truth about withholding national security funding through witnesses and the release of documents. Instead, these senators let the president‚Äôs team order potential witnesses to refuse to testify at House hearings in a blatant cover-up of illegal actions. Senators then blamed House impeachment managers for presenting a ‚Äúweak‚Äù case and gave the lack of such testimony as their primary reason for voting against removing the president.  What is astounding is that we now have a major political party ‚Äî the Republican Party ‚Äî that, with only one exception in the Senate, is no longer serious about its job, its adherence to our sacred constitutional obligations, and doesn‚Äôt have the guts to perform its basic duty to act as a co-equal branch of government and a check on out of control presidential power. Even supporters of the president must realize that the conduct of Republican senators during this process was not an act of bravery, but simply a falling in line so that they wouldn‚Äôt be challenged in their own primary if they dug too deep. They are now a party drifting about with no moral compass, lost at sea, and unable to recognize right from wrong. It now rests in the hands of all of us ‚Äî the voters of all political stripes ‚Äî to reject elected officials who don‚Äôt have the courage to be more than a rubber stamp for their own political party.

Dr. King‚Äôs courage inspires me to continue fighting for a Kentucky, and a nation, where every citizen is accorded an equal right to vote, to access affordable health care, to receive an excellent education, and to be treated with dignity and respect.

Community colleges like Ashland Community & Technical College have made the American dream accessible to thousands of Kentuckians. We must invest in education and training so financial stability is within the grasp of all Kentuckians.

Mitch McConnell just indicated he is going to renege on his Constitutional duty. I put my life on the line for the Constitution... in three combat tours. I will continue to defend it in the Senate, but I have to have your help to get there.

I called for an inquiry because of the grave national security implications of the Commander in Chief withholding vital military security assistance to an ally under attack from Russian forces, and because of the alarming allegation that this was done in exchange to further the president‚Äôs personal domestic political interests.  The testimony we heard in the House hearings was deeply troubling and I will be watching the Senate trial closely. Americans demand to know all of the facts, and Senator McConnell must hold a full and fair process and fulfill his constitutional role. Voters are fed up with politicians like Senator McConnell who show themselves vacant of any moral compass or patriotic courage, and whose public statements are guided by just one metric - which team you are on.  The toxic culture of our politics is no longer about what‚Äôs best for our country. For too many, it's about your party or your donors. As the leader of the Senate, it is McConnell's job to hold our president accountable for any actions that undermine our rule of law and put our nation at risk from foreign interference in our democracy, and that includes compelling the administration to comply with congressional subpoenas to provide evidence and witness testimony.   Senator McConnell lectured our nation that no one is above the law or their oath to the Constitution the last time a president was facing an impeachment trial. Apparently, his principles only apply to those of the other party. Not his own.  My principles aren‚Äôt conditional.

text: This is incredible‚Äîhere's to breaking barriers. #AllWomanSpacewalkTune in to watch the first #AllWomanSpacewalk! Starting at approximately 7:50 a.m. EDT on Friday, Oct. 18, NASA Astronauts Christina Koch and Jessica Meir will set their spacesuits to battery power before venturing outside of the International Space Station for a 5.5 hour spacewalk.  The duo will work in the vacuum of space to replace a power controller that failed over the weekend. Watch:

I‚Äôm humbled by all of the support we‚Äôve received during our first quarter. We raised $10.7 million with an average contribution of just $36. Here‚Äôs the best part: We‚Äôve got all of Kentucky on this team, with donors from every one of our 120 counties. Thank you so much.  This campaign will be long, and our opponent is going to do whatever it takes to defend his seat in Washington. Today, I want to reflect on the grassroots movement we‚Äôre building with you. We‚Äôre going to defeat Mitch and defend democracy. And we‚Äôre going to do it together.

‚Ä™We‚Äôve been at war in Afghanistan for 18 years. But Congress has punted its constitutional responsibility to vote on authorizing the use of force in countries all over the globe. Here are my thoughts as someone who‚Äôs served with our partners overseas.

October is Domestic Violence Awareness Month. But because of Mitch McConnell, it‚Äôs been more than 6 months since the Violence Against Women Act expired. Every day since, he‚Äôs decided there were more important things to do than protect Kentucky women. Kentucky leads the nation in reported cases of stalking and one in three Kentucky women is a victim of domestic violence.  If you or someone you know is affected by domestic violence, get help by calling 1-800-799-7233.

Last weekend, I talked to Kentucky‚Äôs own Pantsuit Politics about how Kentucky needs a senator who isn‚Äôt just another career politician. I‚Äôve served our country overseas and now I‚Äôm running to serve Kentucky in the Senate.

The allegations surrounding whether President Trump pressured the Ukrainian leader to investigate the family of his political rival are, if true, a disgraceful betrayal of the oath of office and demand immediate action by Congress. No matter who is sitting in the Oval Office, our international power and national security can never be used for personal political gain. It's embarrassing and alarming that Sen. McConnell can't find the patriotic courage to speak out and demand that the whistleblower complaint be delivered to Congress, as required by law. We need to get to the truth of these allegations immediately.

It should be easier for Kentuckians to get affordable health care, but Mitch McConnell is supporting a lawsuit that would actually make it more difficult. If he got his way rural hospitals could close and folks could be denied coverage for their pre-existing conditions.
I‚Äôm running for Senate because we can do better. We must expand health care protections, protect our elections, and defend social security and medicare. That‚Äôs what Kentucky deserves.

Today I spoke to Georgetown College students about leadership and my experiences this day eighteen years ago. I was glad to take a question from Madison, who's interested in serving our country too.

On September 11, 2001, I sat strapped in the back seat of a fully loaded two-seat F/A-18 jet just off runway 24L at the Marine Corps Air Station Miramar in San Diego, engines running, ready to launch at a moment‚Äôs notice. Two planes had already crashed into the World Trade Center, and another had crashed into the Pentagon. If required, my section of two fighter jets would intercept any passenger airliner that wasn‚Äôt responding to air traffic control‚Äôs commands and could have been attacking Los Angeles or San Diego. I listened intently, as each new radio call could have been the one that ordered us airborne. At the age of 26, in that cockpit on 9/11, I hoped and prayed that the leadership of my country knew what was best. I would do my part to defend us should I be called. In the end, we were never given a call to launch, but the intensity of that experience was unforgettable‚Äîand a reminder that the responsibilities of leadership are immense. We need leaders we can trust‚Äîleaders who are competent, who have the courage to step up, and do what is best for our country. The tragedies of 9/11 can never be undone, and I mourn the victims who lost their lives that day and those who have been permanently affected in its aftermath. America‚Äôs response to that event 18 years ago reminds me of the fabric and resilience of our nation. It speaks of our capacity to look past divisions, come together and act for the common good. Today, I‚Äôll be reflecting on that lesson, and resolve to continue to do my part in the defense of our nation.

Student loan debt is crippling many Kentuckians. But, under Betsy Devos‚Äô leadership, the Department of Education has rejected 99% of applications for student loan forgiveness. That won‚Äôt fly when I‚Äôm in the Senate.

Erik and I had a great time at the Kentucky Democratic Party‚Äôs Wendell Ford Dinner last night. It was especially wonderful to see Gov. Paul and Judi Patton and Steve Ford, Sen. Wendell Ford‚Äôs son. Thanks to Lynn and Lt. Gov. Crit Luallen, Rep. Angie Hatton, Judge Denise Brown, and Priscilla Fogle Johnson for joining us at our table.

Mitch McConnell likes to talk about how powerful he is, but now that $62 million in funding for Ft. Campbell Middle School is being raided‚Äîmoney that McConnell took credit for securing‚Äîhe's passing the buck. Kentucky‚Äôs military families deserve better.

My little girl has an ear infection and refuses to take any medication that tastes ‚Äúicky,‚Äù so I went to Kroger to grab some strawberry syrup. I found the syrup‚Äîmission accomplished!‚Äîand at the self checkout, I was approached by a woman named Mary. She‚Äôs been crushed by health care costs; her insurance premiums keep getting higher and higher.  Mary had to get surgery recently. She has no idea how she‚Äôll pay her deductible, even with her full-time job as a bookkeeper. She had to sell her house and move into an apartment with a friend. And she hasn‚Äôt gotten a raise in over a decade. Mary grew up middle class herself and brought up eight children of her own. This is what‚Äôs happening to folks in this economy‚Äîthey‚Äôre being crushed by health care costs and stagnating wages.  We‚Äôve got to get health care costs down and wages up for Kentuckians. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm running.

This afternoon, I had the honor of speaking at the United Mine Workers of America meeting in Lexington.  When Mitch McConnell had the power to do anything he wanted‚Äîhe could've passed a jobs bill, lowered drug prices, or fully-funded the Black Lung Trust Fund‚Äîhe instead passed a tax cut for folks like him.

We'll never be able to make progress in this country with Mitch McConnell in the Senate. Over his 34-year career in Washington, he's reveled in his ability to obstruct even the most common sense measures. We can't stand for kicking the can down the road any longer.

‚Ä™This morning, Erik and I brought our kids out to the Bluegrass Central Labor Council Labor Day Picnic to celebrate the workers and unions that helped build Kentucky‚Äôs middle class. And because Teddy really wanted to see the fire trucks.‚Ä¨

Natalia and I went through flight school together. Eleven years later, we deployed to Helmand Province, Afghanistan, at the same time. Today, I watched her be promoted to the rank of Commander (US Navy). Congratulations my friend!
We're looking for interns! Kentucky students, sign up here to join Team McGrath:
Mitch McConnell is bad for coal miners. Just ask them.
Before we can defeat Mitch McConnell in 2020, we need to beat Matt Bevin this November. Sign up to help üëáüèª

This is what I love about traveling around Kentucky‚Äîstopped by Heritage Kitchen in Whitesburg for lunch today and got to talk with folks about issues facing their families, and learn more about how we can support them. Thanks to all who came by‚Äîespecially Mayor James Craft.

This morning, for Women's Equality Day, I went to Breaking the Bronze Ceiling's event announcing a monument honoring the contributions of women. Downtown Lexington currently has no statues recognizing women‚Äîwe're going to change that. It was great to reflect on the long fight for equality and to speak with some of Kentucky's most accomplished women.

Our coal miners risked their lives to fuel our country‚Äîbut Mitch McConnell would only give a group of them with black lung disease a scant minute when they rode 10 hours to visit him in Washington. My question for McConnell: Which side are you on?
With Ellie starting school, and George and Teddy heading back, I dug up a photo from when I was around my daughter's age. I bet you'll see the resemblance. #TBT

I had such a warm welcome in Western Kentucky this week‚Äîthanks to Paducah, Henderson, Owensboro, Bowling Green, and Elizabethtown!  Mitch McConnell broke Washington, but, together with folks all across Kentucky, we can fix it.
It was so much fun visiting with folks in Elizabethtown this afternoon‚Äîand check out the great T-shirt on LTC Jack Morrison, US Army Chaplain Corps (Ret.)!
Really enjoyed talking with folks at breakfast early this morning in Bowling Green!
Met with a few supporters and friends in Paducah this afternoon. Great to see everyone!
Ellie's first day of preschool was this week. She is growing so fast!

We‚Äôve been at war for 18 years now. For those of us who‚Äôve served, it‚Äôs important we not forget this. That‚Äôs why I try to highlight every time an American servicemember makes the ultimate sacrifice in overseas operations‚Äîthese wars have a cost. For almost a decade, Congress has punted its constitutional responsibility to authorize America's use of force. Servicemembers have the courage to put their lives on the line on foreign soil and we need elected leaders who (at least) have the courage to debate whether we should be there.

Evan in Covington gave $5 to our campaign, so I called and said thank you! This campaign is fueled by grassroots donors like him. Join Team McGrath: https://secure.actblue.com/donate/mcgrath2020-social?refcode=190812fb

Kentucky‚Äôs family farms are in crisis. Over the 34 years that Mitch McConnell has been in Washington, we‚Äôve lost 10,000 family farms. And, during the same period, he‚Äôs taken almost $4 million from big ag.

Teddy (pilot) and Ellie (the gunner) flew their cardboard attack aircraft on a mission this past week. The cockpit is state of the art‚Äîwith a black sharpie drawn throttle, stick, rudder pedals and instruments.

I visited the Blackjewel miners in Harlan County today. These miners and their families haven't been able to pay their bills because the company won't pay them what they're owed. This situation is terrible, but these miners are handling it the American way‚Äîwith an effective, peaceful protest. I'll continue to do everything I can to help them.

I stand with Kentucky miners. The first priority for Blackjewel must be paying their workers what they're owed.A train carrying out coal from the Cloverlick mine in Harlan County has brought out these former Blackjewel miners. They tell me they still have not been paid, and refuse to let this train leave with the coal they worked to get.

Mitch McConnell has spent his 34 years in office creating the Washington swamp instead of representing Kentuckians. I‚Äôm a mom, retired Marine, wife, and fighter pilot. My next mission is defeating him.  I hope you‚Äôll join our team:

I‚Äôm running for Senate because most Kentuckians can‚Äôt afford their own lobbying firm. Kentucky coal miners‚Äîmany battling black lung disease‚Äîspent ten hours riding a bus from Eastern Kentucky, just to be blown off by Mitch McConnell. I‚Äôll tell you this: I‚Äôm sure he‚Äôd never treat a special interest lobbyist this way. ‚Äú‚ÄòWe rode up here for 10 hours by bus to get some answers from him because he represents our state,‚Äô said George Massey, a miner from Harlan County, Kentucky who spent two decades in the mines and is on disability. ‚ÄòFor him to come in for just two minutes was a low-down shame.‚Äô‚Äù

Mitch McConnell has been in Washington for so long‚Äî34 years‚Äîthat he‚Äôs forgotten the people who sent him there. He has failed coal miners time after time, and now he‚Äôs making them travel to DC to ask for help. He‚Äôs jeopardizing funding for folks with black lung disease. The most important thing to come out of a coal mine is coal miners. I hope McConnell listens to these hardworking folks today.

Like so many other Americans, I had a blast watching the U.S. Women‚Äôs National Soccer Team win the World Cup this month. Throughout the tournament, they defined excellence‚Äîscoring impressive goals, playing solid defense, and rising to every single challenge. I learned many of my most important lessons growing up on the soccer field and on the basketball court. At Notre Dame Academy, I learned perseverance, composure and teamwork‚Äîthat when you miss a tackle or a shot, you‚Äôve got to pick yourself back up, brush it off, focus and get back into the game. That‚Äôs how I succeeded at the Naval Academy, on and off the field. The women of the USWNT brought their own message for all of us this summer‚Äîequal pay for equal work. Despite being the best in the world, the Women‚Äôs National Team could earn significantly less than what the men‚Äôs team does for the same number of wins. On average, in our country women earn only about 80 cents for every dollar men do.  We deserve better, but we won‚Äôt be able to get equal pay with Mitch McConnell in the Senate. He‚Äôs been obstructing the bipartisan Paycheck Fairness Act that passed the House. That‚Äôs one of many reasons I‚Äôm running to defeat Mitch and defend democracy.

Opioids are ravaging Kentucky and destroying our families. The pharmaceutical industry flooded our state with almost 2 billion prescription pain pills over six years. Mitch McConnell has taken $1.34 million from pharmaceutical companies. Do the math.

Our campaign is fueled by grassroots energy from thousands of folks across the commonwealth. After an incredible first week, I‚Äôve been calling Kentuckians like Daniel to say thank you. I couldn‚Äôt do this without you on my team.

Election security is national security, and as a Marine, I know this should never be a partisan issue. McConnell is putting our nation‚Äôs security at risk by refusing to prioritize protecting our elections.

Our average contribution is just $34! I'm so excited that there are tens of thousands of people in this fight to give Kentuckians their voices back. For too long, Mitch McConnell has been turning Washington into the corrupt swamp we all hate. Thank you for joining this fight!

Going up against one of the dirtiest deep-pocketed politicians in DC isn‚Äôt going to be easy. But you all showed us I‚Äôm not alone in this fight. We‚Äôre coming for him. Chip in now to help us defeat Mitch:
Washington is broken. Mitch McConnell broke it. We can fix it.

I‚Äôm running to replace Mitch McConnell in the U.S. Senate. Everything that‚Äôs wrong with Washington had to start somewhere‚Äîit started with him. He‚Äôs a career politician who‚Äôs been in the Senate for a lifetime, and all he has to show for it is a trail of corruption and obstruction. Health care, budgets, and the Supreme Court are his hostages, to be wielded as a weapon against anyone who dares to oppose him. I‚Äôm not a career politician. I‚Äôm a daughter, a mom, a wife, a retired Marine, and a fighter pilot. I know this is going to be a tough fight‚ÄîMitch literally invented modern negative campaigning‚Äîbut I‚Äôm ready for it. Defeat Mitch. Defend Democracy. Join us: www.AmyMcGrath.com

Happy pride from George and Ellie! The rainbow flavored ice cream achieved meltdown in the 90 degree heat in about 2 minutes. Luckily, the kids lasted longer than that. We had so much fun at Lexington Pride Festival.

Erik and I were happy to be a part of the Appalachian Veteran Project‚Äôs ‚Äústanddown‚Äù to bring awareness of the resources our fellow Kentuckians can provide to our veteran community. Services on hand to help included optometrists from the University of Pikeville, housing assistance, local VFW, medical trucks from the Veterans Health Administration (VHA) - U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, and counseling services. Read more in The Morehead News:

We have veterans here in Kentucky who may be struggling with access to medical care, affordability of a home, or finding a good job. A lot of times, as veterans, we don‚Äôt like to ask for help when we need it. I know this. That‚Äôs why Erik and I are thankful we had the opportunity to join the Appalachian Veteran Project in West Liberty this afternoon. Today, the project hosted a ‚Äústanddown‚Äù in Morgan County to reach out to veterans who may be in need and help offer them resources to build a better quality of life. I‚Äôm proud they once stepped up to serve our country and we want them to know that our community and our Commonwealth care about how they are doing today and in the future.

When I was a girl who wanted to be a fighter pilot everyone told me I couldn't do it, but I didn't give up.  It's always an honor to speak to groups of ambitious young Kentucky women who're chasing their dreams. Thanks for having me, Lead Kentucky!‚Ä™She‚Äôs a fan favorite, as always! Thank you for your support, Amy McGrath! #TakeTheLead‚Ä¨

I was honored to be the Grand Marshal of the Park Hills, KY Memorial Day Parade. It was wonderful to do the parade ride with Sr. Mary Ethel Parrott, SND, Provincial Superior, Sisters of Notre Dame, Covington, Kentucky (also my physics teacher at Notre Dame Academy way back when).  Got a chance to talk with some JROTC cadets about service. Thank you to Park Hills for allowing me to share the stories of my friends who have perished while serving our country. Happy Memorial Day.

My fellow Kentuckians,  TOMORROW your vote is important. There is much we need to work on in our Commonwealth, and you are needed to be a participant, not an observer.  For so many around the world, voting isn‚Äôt an option. Many Americans perished to allow us this right. Here in KY in 2019, I‚Äôd argue it‚Äôs a responsibility.  Tomorrow, May 21st the polls are open from 6 AM to 6 PM. Find out your polling location here:  https://vrsws.sos.ky.gov/VIC/
I'm honored to be the inspiration behind Samantha‚Äôs 7th grade ‚Äúwax museum‚Äù project at Immaculate Heart of Mary school. I see big things in her future! Hope you got an A!
Looking forward to being apart of Appalachian Veteran Project's Operation Stand Down on June 22nd!
Wonderful to speak at the Women Leading Kentucky Roundtable about overcoming challenges in my life and lessons I‚Äôve learned along the way. Thanks for having me!

Enjoyed the weekend watching the Thunder Over Louisville Airshow and seeing F/A-18s, Black Knights, B-52s, C-130s, and Warbirds. I also got to talk aviation to Louisville‚Äôs Flight Club 502 - a group of hardworking motivated teens who love flying. My son, George was not as interested...maybe someday.
Congrats to the Campbellsville University - Harrodsburg Lady Tigers on a phenomenal first season. Enjoyed meeting the team and their families and seeing the campus! CU-Harrodsburg Athletics

source: Amy McGrath,Ashland, The Henry Clay Estate
text: Enjoyed my visit to the Ashland, The Henry Clay Estate. Great to be back!We had a surprise visitor this past week, who like many of us, make Ashland a must-see with out-of-town guests. Amy said the last time she visited was in a school field trip. Don‚Äôt wait for houseguests - join our new tour ‚ÄúWomen‚Äôs Voices‚Äù Every Fri/Sat @ 2:30pm. #sharethelex

My friend and fellow Marine Aviator, Colonel Richard Bew (Ret.), is running in the fast approaching Special Election in #NC03 If you think we need more public servants, not politicians, in DC, who will always put #CountryOverParty please follow and support Richard Bew for Congress. www.richardbew.com

‚ÄúThe work of today is the history of tomorrow, and we are its makers.‚Äù -Juliette Gordon Low (founder of the Girl Scouts of America in 1912) It‚Äôs hard to believe March is here. Last month, my family and I took a short trek south to warmer weather. Our ‚Äúfun and relaxing‚Äù trip to visit Mickey Mouse was fun, but relaxing with three kids?... not so much.  March is Women‚Äôs History Month and this week I had to the opportunity to be a part of the first annual ‚ÄúGirl Talk‚Äù at Northern Elementary School in Lexington. I was joined by other professional, passionate women to discuss our careers with the hope of demonstrating to 4th and 5th-grade girls that they can be anything they want to be. It was wonderful being involved in this event helping to inspire the future of our country.   I remember what it was like growing up and being that age here in Kentucky. What I wanted to do with my life was not open to me as a girl.  So many of my own opportunities were made possible thanks to the courageous women of the past who were willing to reach beyond what society told them they could do. As I listened to the girls‚Äô questions, it struck me that one or two of them might have goals that seem impossible to achieve right now. Hopefully, "Girl Talk" will remind them to work hard, dream big, and not give up. It‚Äôs a lesson for us all. If you want to sign up to join my email list you can do so here: https://act.myngp.com/Forms/105632347178535680
